item.title: Oscar Nominations: ‘Sinners’ Breaks Record With 16
item.description: “One Battle After Another” was close behind with 13 nods. Acting nominees include Michael B. Jordan, Kate Hudson, Timothée Chalamet and Teyana Taylor.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

item.title: 2026 Oscar Nominations: See the Full List
item.description: The movies competing for the 98th Academy Awards. The ceremony will air on March 15.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez and Kellina Moore
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
Little Amelie or the Character of Rain (Movie)

item.title: Oscar Snubs and Surprises: ‘Sinners’ Makes History, ‘Wicked’ Withers
item.description: Ariana Grande, Chase Infiniti and Paul Mescal were shut out, but voters made room for Delroy Lindo, Kate Hudson and “F1.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Five Fronts in Trump’s Culture War
item.description: In the first year of his second term, President Trump has made sweeping efforts to influence the arts and media in America.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: During a White House dinner in October, President Trump showed models of a triumphal arch he is planning to build in Washington.

item.title: When Jasper Johns Drew the Line
item.description: A new exhibition revisits a turning point in the career of the 95-year-old artist: the paintings that faced down death to find meaning in life.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Jasper Johns/Licensed by VAGA at Artists Rights Society (ARS), NY; Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Detail, Jasper Johns, “Between the Clock and the Bed,” 1981, at Gagosian. After painting targets and flags, he turned to a new kind of markmaking: crosshatch abstractions whose fidgety lines trace the artist’s earthly path from anxiety to acceptance of mortality.

item.title: Jason Mantzoukas Makes It Weird
item.description: As TV’s go-to maniac, the actor has a flair for chaos that also functions as a kind of emotional armor. “I’m still very protective of the actual me,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Percy Jackson and the Olympians (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Michael Tyrone Delaney for The New York Times
item.media:description: It may surprise fans to learn that offstage and off mic, Jason Mantzoukas is pleasantly normal.

item.title: ‘Sinners’ Broke the Oscars Record These 3 Films Once Held
item.description: As categories evolved over time, the way to make academy history did, too. But for decades, no film topped 14 nods, until “Sinners” smashed the record.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Harry Styles Books 30 Dates for Madison Square Garden Residency
item.description: The pop star is returning with his fourth solo album on March 6. His Together, Together tour, which will hit seven cities, is scheduled to begin in May.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.category: Kiss All the Time. Disco, Occasionally. (Album)
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Harry Styles onstage at Madison Square Garden in 2022. The pop star will return to the arena for 30 dates this year.

item.title: A Public-Art Veteran Will Lead Creative Time
item.description: Jean Cooney, a former deputy director of the New York City public-art institution, is the organization’s next leader.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets

item.title: These Objects Will Draw You Out of the Cold
item.description: Among scores of artworks, these 9 light up the Winter Show at the Park Avenue Armory, featuring more than 70 international dealers.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: These three-foot-long “slap shoes” were used by the 4’6” English vaudevillian Harry Relph, known as “Little Tich,” who could balance on the toes, on view at the Winter Show at the Park Avenue Armory.

item.title: ‘H Is for Hawk’ Review: All Shall Be Well
item.description: Claire Foy stars along with a goshawk in an adaptation of Helen MacDonald’s award-winning memoir.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Mercy’ Review: Chris Pratt Trapped in a Dystopian Future
item.description: Chris Pratt plays a man accused of killing his wife in this witless action-thriller where harsh justice is dispensed by artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Months After Daniel Naroditsky’s Death, the Chess World Remains Divided
item.description: The death of Daniel Naroditsky exposed the conflicts between the game’s traditional wing and its many online stars.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: Esa-Pekka Salonen Returns to L.A. Philharmonic With New Job
item.description: Esa-Pekka Salonen, the orchestra’s longtime music director, came back to lead his first concerts since being named its creative director.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Episode 3 Recap: Expect the Unexpected
item.description: The doctors are seeing a lot of rare cases on this Fourth of July. Not even the fireworks-related injuries have been straightforward.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: Warrick Page/HBO Max
item.media:description: When Dr. Al-Hashimi (Sepideh Moafi) isn’t butting heads with Dr. Robby, she has excellent bedside manner.

item.title: James Bernard, a Founding Editor of a Hip-Hop ‘Bible,’ Dies at 58
item.description: One of the most influential voices of the seminal magazine The Source, he chronicled rap’s rise and its explosion into the cultural mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: The Cliburn, Known for Piano Competitions, Will Hold One for Conductors
item.description: The trailblazing conductor Marin Alsop will chair the jury for the inaugural Cliburn International Competition for Conductors in 2028.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The idea for the new competition came from Marin Alsop, the first woman to be the music director of a top-tier U.S. orchestra.

item.title: Fine Arts Panel, Remade by Trump, Indicates Support for His Ballroom Plan
item.description: The president has stacked a commission with allies as he has pushed to construct a 90,000-square-foot addition to the White House. A federal judge signaled he might block the project.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: A rendering of the proposed White House ballroom in the Oval Office last month.

item.title: Stream These 8 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in February
item.description: A couple of horror classics, a beloved sitcom and a great Paul Thomas Anderson film are among the gems leaving for U.S. subscribers next month.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.media:credit: Melinda Sue Gordon/Metro Goldwyn Mayer Pictures
item.media:description: Cooper Hoffman, left, and Alana Haim, center, in the Paul Thomas Anderson film “Licorice Pizza.”

item.title: Where to Stream the 2026 Oscar Nominees: ‘Sinners,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and More
item.description: Many of the top contenders can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to help you get a jump on the field.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

item.title: ‘Clika’ Review: Dreaming of the Stage
item.description: This film about a fieldworker trying to make it in music offers a Mexican American spin on underdog dreamer movies like “8 Mile.”
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: A 67,800-Year-Old Handprint May Be the World’s Oldest Rock Art
item.description: “It was hiding in plain sight all this time,” one researcher said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Yan Zhuang

item.title: The Exacting, Ephemeral Art of Ice Carving
item.description: A look inside a Queens studio where Buddhas, sneakers and swans are carved with reverence and the knowledge that beauty, like ice, is fleeting.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and Erin Schaff

item.title: America Turns 250: A Guide to the Coming Festivities
item.description: Girl Scouts singing folk songs, a flag-waving party and a Times Square ball drop are among the planned Semiquincentennial celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Return to Silent Hill’ Review: A Macabre Spectacle
item.description: This latest installment in the video game movie franchise looks like it’s meant to be played.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘In Cold Light’ Review: On Parole and on the Run
item.description: In this dreary thriller, an ex-con faces escalating dangers and familial strife when she attempts to regain control of her drug operation.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘A New Love in Tokyo’ Review: Sex in the Air
item.description: The erotic film, first shown in 1994, finds room for sweetness with its kink.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Disneyland Handcrafted’ Review: Making the Happiest Place on Earth
item.description: Leslie Iwerks’s documentary is a captivating look at the creative and logistical challenges of building a beloved theme park on California farmland.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Linden

item.title: ‘Mr. Nobody Against Putin’ Review: Indoctrination in the Classroom
item.description: A primary schoolteacher in Russia documents the government’s efforts to teach students pro-war messages.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: Kimmel Says Comedy Is Political Lately Because Politics Are Comedic
item.description: “We didn’t come to them, they came to us,” the late night host said about news infiltrating comedy while discussing President Trump’s latest stab for Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Manolo Villaverde, Tender Father on Bilingual TV Show, Dies at 89
item.description: He played Pepe Peña on “¿Qué Pasa, U.S.A.?,” a series about a Cuban American family that is believed to be the United States’ first bilingual sitcom.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Jose A. Iglesias/Miami Herald/Tribune News Service, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Manolo Villaverde in 2017. As Pepe Peña, “he was the father figure that we were used to,” the executive producer of “¿Qué Pasa, U.S.A.?” said.

item.title: Prue Leith Says She Is Leaving ‘The Great British Baking Show’
item.description: Ms. Leith, 86, presided over more than 400 challenges in nine seasons of the TV baking competition, and says it “feels like the right time.”
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.category: The Great British Bake Off (TV Program)
The Great British Baking Show (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Jim Dyson/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prue Leith hosting at a festival in Charlbury, Oxfordshire, in August.

item.title: Saving La Clef Cinema, With Help From Scorsese and Tarantino
item.description: After a saga that kept its supporters on the edge of their seats for years, a beloved art-house cinema is now open for business once more, run by volunteers this time.
item.dc:creator: Hester Underhill

item.title: How a Pro-Greenland Song Became a Protest Anthem
item.description: Locals are speaking out against President Trump’s gestures toward annexing the territory, and the song “Greenland Belongs to Greenlanders” has become “a soundtrack of the movement.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest over President Trump’s wish to take over Greenland in Nuuk, the capital, last week.

item.title: What ‘Marty Supreme’ Says About Being Jewish in America
item.description: The film’s unapologetic depiction of the experience in all of its complications rejects the idea that such characters have to suffer.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Timothée Chalamet as Marty Mauser, who is not a model minority by any means.

item.title: How Ralph Fiennes Rocks Out to Iron Maiden in ‘The Bone Temple’
item.description: One scene from the continuation of “28 Years Later” has Fiennes’s character performing to the song “The Number of the Beast.” A look at how the filmmakers pulled it off.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: What a Road Trip to Badlands National Park With My Son Taught Me
item.description: How a road trip with his son led Sam Graham-Felsen to a different understanding of “tough.”
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Davis Land, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Sonia Herrero, Pat McCusker, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Dan Powell

item.title: At New York Performance Festivals, Finding the Dance in Theater
item.description: January is not a dry month for performance in New York, and this season, there were wide-ranging views of how bodies — more than words — can tell stories.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: At the Kochi Art Biennale, South Asia Meets Brazil
item.description: Asia’s largest noncommercial art event recruited from all corners of the globe, “breaking the stereotypes of what it means to be making contemporary art in India.”
item.dc:creator: Walker Mimms
item.media:credit: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times
item.media:description: ‘Death Circle’ by artist Krisha Murthy P S at BMS Warehouse in Kochi.

item.title: ‘Kidnapped: Elizabeth Smart’ Review: A Survivor Speaks Out
item.description: In this documentary, Smart tells the frightening narrative of her 2002 kidnapping at age 14, in Utah.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: 10 Long Books to Cozy Up With This Winter
item.description: Fantasy epics, pastoral classics and family dramas provide something to sink your teeth into on cold evenings.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.category: A Song of Ice and Fire (Book)

item.title: Late Night Cringes Over Trump’s Texting Spree
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel quipped that the president “can do so much damage in one three-day weekend — I don’t know if anybody has ever done more.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Georges Borchardt, 97, Dies; Literary Agent Championed Wiesel’s ‘Night’
item.description: Renowned in his field, he counted among his clients five Nobel laureates, including Elie Wiesel, and eight Pulitzer winners as well as the estates of Tennessee Williams and Aldous Huxley.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger

item.title: Despite Drastic Financial Steps, Met Opera Turns to Layoffs and Cuts
item.description: The largest performing arts organization in the country will lay off workers, cut salaries and reduce its offerings. It may also sell its Chagall murals that are valued at $55 million.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon/Reuters
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Opera announced a $200 million deal with Saudi Arabia last year after drawing $120 million from its endowment.

item.title: ‘Mel Brooks: The 99 Year Old Man!’ Is a Funny, Bittersweet Tribute
item.description: Co-directed by Judd Apatow, the two-part HBO series is an exhaustive look at Brooks’s life and comedy. It is also about longevity and loneliness.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: Mel Brooks: The 99 Year Old Man! (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Mel Brooks/HBO
item.media:description: Mel Brooks in younger days with his wife Anne Bancroft. Their marriage lasted over 40 years.

item.title: 10 Gloriously Nonsensical Songs of Pop Gibberish
item.description: “Sussudio,” “Di Doo Dah,” “Da Doo Ron Ron” and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Clemens Bilan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Phil Collins, the maestro of “Sussudio.”

item.title: The World’s Reigning Carmen Breaks Down Her Signature Aria
item.description: Aigul Akhmetshina, performing now at the Met, shares her thoughts on what it takes to bring the famous Habanera to life.
item.dc:creator: Oussama Zahr
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Makes Its Impact Felt Onscreen and Off
item.description: The breakout show about two hockey players in love has gone from a TV hit to IRL social sensation.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Lloyd Bishop/NBC, via Getty Images; Kevork Djansezian/CBS; Todd Owyoung/NBC, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Connor Storrie and Hudson Williams have been making the rounds, from “Late Night” to the Golden Globes. But the way “Heated Rivalry” has exploded off the screen shows its far-reaching impact.

item.title: Now Boarding the Freedom Plane: Precious Founding-Era Documents
item.description: The plane, organized by the National Archives, will take rare 18th-century documents around the country in a tour loosely inspired by the Bicentennial’s Freedom Train.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: National Archives
item.media:description: A rendering of the Freedom Plane, which will carry precious documents from the American Founding to eight cities starting in March.

item.title: 2026 Oscar Nomination Predictions
item.description: “Sinners” and “One Battle After Another” could set a record. Expect them to be up for best picture with “Hamnet,” “Frankenstein” and “Marty Supreme.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Rewatching ‘Mad Men’ From the Outskirts
item.description: The series was known for its sharp scripting, artful acting and attentive wardrobe and set design. But it brought little of that meticulousness to its Black characters.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
item.media:credit: AMC
item.media:description: As the Draper family’s housekeeper, Carla (Deborah Lacey) was a witness to, and a kind of silent judge of, their petty dramas.

item.title: The Charming Raconteur Semyon Bychkov’s Next Job: Music Director at Paris Opera
item.description: Semyon Bychkov will soon take up the most prestigious post of his long, varied career. Collaborating with Ralph Fiennes on “Eugene Onegin,” he gives a taste of things to come.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Semyon Bychkov at the Palais Garnier in Paris.

item.title: President Trump’s Chosen Artist? A Christian Speed Painter.
item.description: Vanessa Horabuena has painted presidential portraits and Jesus for Mr. Trump, and this month, he sold one of her paintings for $2.75 million in a charity auction.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vanessa Horabuena, whom President Trump has called “one of the greatest artists anywhere in the world.”

item.title: Book Review: ‘Tangerinn,’ by Emanuela Anechoum
item.description: In Emanuela Anechoum’s novel, “Tangerinn,” an Italian Moroccan woman examines her family’s legacy of immigration, and tries to find a place in the world.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib

item.title: The Secretive V.I.P. Programs That Keep Gamers Spending
item.description: Lucrative players of games like FarmVille and Words With Friends get personal account managers and entries to exclusive sweepstakes.
item.dc:creator: Michael Thomsen

item.title: Filoplumes Are Nature’s Super Feather
item.description: Filoplumes may be tiny, but these hairlike feathers enable nonstop flights that span thousands of miles.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins and Bryan Anselm
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: Jimmy Fallon Teases Trump Over Secondhand Prize
item.description: The “Tonight Show” host joked that President Trump hung his new Nobel Prize on the wall “right next to his McDonald’s customer of the month plaque.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: How the Cleveland Orchestra Stays at the Top of Classical Music
item.description: Our critic tracked one concert, from its first rehearsals to its first performance. Practice is only part of what makes this ensemble excellent.
item.dc:creator: David Allen
item.media:credit: Daniel Lozada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Franz Welser-Möst, the Cleveland Orchestra’s longtime music director, during a rehearsal for one of the ensemble’s concerts this month.

item.title: ‘Roofman,’ ‘While We’re Young’ and More Streaming Gems
item.description: This month’s guide to the under-the-radar movies of your subscription services includes unconventional romantic comedies and vibrant indie dramas.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.category: The Stringer: The Man Who Took the Photo (Movie)

item.title: ‘An Unbelievable Mess’: Artists Are Stymied by Trump Travel Bans
item.description: Musicians, theater groups and others from overseas are facing visa challenges and rising costs, posing a looming crisis for the performing arts sector.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Douglas Mason/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tinariwen canceled an American tour when the Trump administration announced travel restrictions on 19 countries, including Mali, where most of its members are from.

item.title: How a Shoe Invented by a Dancer Might Be a Game Changer
item.description: Ballet evolves slowly, and that includes footwear. But a new shoe with sneaker technology is giving dancers support from the heel up.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
